title: How to Use Your Canned Spinach

steps.title: Keep it simple.
steps.content: Keep it simple. Warmed-up canned spinach has a wonderfully simple, refreshing taste that is complemented well with one to two tablespoons of lemon juice or red wine vinegar per can and a sprinkling of bacon (or bacon bits, for the less culinarily-inclined). Top with a little melted butter if you would like.

steps.title: Add seasoning.
steps.content: Add seasoning. Canned spinach on its own is quite yummy, but can easily be enhanced using basic spices and toppings. Popular toppings include garlic powder, dry mustard, chopped tomatoes, olives, feta cheese, crushed red pepper, and bacon bits.

steps.title: Mix it into pasta sauce.
steps.content: Mix it into pasta sauce. Canned spinach can very easily be blended into tomato sauce, or spread across lasagna sheets as a filling. Well complemented with tomatoes, basil, and ricotta, canned spinach can pretty much be incorporated into any tomato-and-pasta recipe.

steps.title: Cook it in butter with onions.
steps.content: Cook it in butter with onions. Although it is little more decadent than your standard heart-healthy dish, it is still highly nutritious. Sauté a chopped onion with two tablespoons of butter until browned, then add spinach and cook through.

steps.title: Add it to meatballs and meatloaf.
steps.content: Add it to meatballs and meatloaf. Add ½-1 can of canned spinach per pound of meat and mix with bread crumbs, veggies, and whatever other ingredients you usually add. This makes for a fantastically easy way to get the children to eat their leafy greens.

steps.title: Mix it into scrambled eggs or omelettes.
steps.content: Mix it into scrambled eggs or omelettes. Use one can to every four to five eggs and add some garlic or parmesan cheese if preferred. Season simply with salt and pepper and your eggs are now much more vitamin-rich!

steps.title: Make some spinach pies.
steps.content: Make some spinach pies. Mix a can of spinach with three beaten eggs, some chopped onion, a cup of milk, some chopped bacon, and a few slices of provolone cheese and pour into pie shell and bake at 400 °F (204 °C) for 30-40 minutes.
